title: Fast-forwarding decision making
paper_abstract: The article discusses how organizations waste time in decision making by engaging in the theatre of decision making, which creates delay rather than progress. The author advises holding oneself accountable for making decisions and progressing discussions as quickly as possible by being creative about ways of shaving minutes, hours, and days from a decision point.
subject_orig: decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity
subject: decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity

title: Scrutiny and Judgement
paper_abstract: The scrutiny and judgement faced by public figures is not unique to them. As you progress in your management career, you will find that senior positions invite more scrutiny from your colleagues. The visibility of those in power encourages scrutiny, and during good times, they can be fantastic role models. But during bad times, fingers will be pointed at them, despite the net result of the current situation being generated by the whole organization. Coping strategies for those in positions of power include compartmentalizing their personality into their "work" self and their "home" self, but it can become exhausting. Judgement can come from both directions, and to deal with it, one must be themselves, warts and all.
subject_orig: scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies
subject: scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies

title: The Stick
paper_abstract: The article discusses the use of the "stick" approach to motivate teams to work harder or faster. It explores the reasons why teams may be asked to work harder and the reasons why the stick approach may not work for software engineering teams. The article suggests that the stick approach is not effective for teams that are in an industry where demand for talent is high and where employees are self-motivated.
subject_orig: stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated
subject: stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated

title: Mental Model: Prioritization and Learning
paper_abstract: The blog post discusses the phases of learning a new skill, using software development as an example. It begins with making things work, then making them correct, followed by making them usable and optimizing them. Finally, aesthetics is considered.
subject_orig: mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality
subject: mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality

title: Fast-forwarding decision making
paper_abstract: The article highlights how organizations waste time on decision-making, involving indirect actions that feel like progress but contribute nothing to it. The author suggests holding oneself accountable for making decisions and progressing discussions as quickly as possible, by whatever means necessary, and being creative about ways of shaving minutes, hours, and days from a decision point.
subject_orig: decision-making, progress, accountability, time management, consensus
subject: decision-making, progress, accountability, time management, consensus

title: Coaching for Managers: A Framework for Improving Staff Performance
paper_abstract: The article discusses the importance of coaching as a tool for improving the performance of staff. Coaching is defined as a framework for interactions with colleagues that can have tangible positive effects on their work. The article presents three main concepts of coaching, including the mode of conversation, keeping the thought bubble over the staff's head, and the GROW model. The article emphasizes that coaching doesn't require special planning or skills and can be used in both formal and informal settings.
subject_orig: coaching, staff performance, management, framework, GROW model
subject: coaching, staff performance, management, framework, GROW model

title: Mount Stupid
paper_abstract: The article discusses the psychological concepts of the Dunning-Kruger effect and Impostor syndrome and how they can affect the workplace. The author explains how the Dunning-Kruger effect can lead to poor decisions made by junior engineers and rash decisions made by managerial staff. The article also includes a humorous graph illustrating the most dangerous place in the Dunning-Kruger effect.
subject_orig: Dunning-Kruger effect, Impostor syndrome, workplace, engineering
subject: Dunning-Kruger effect, Impostor syndrome, workplace, engineering

title: Ownership
paper_abstract: In this blog post, James Stanier discusses the importance of taking total ownership of collective output in software development teams. He highlights the common issue of wasted time between phases of work and how individual focus on productivity can cause total productivity of the group to suffer. Stanier suggests that a Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI) can be useful in clarifying roles and responsibilities within a team, but emphasizes that ownership is primarily a change in mindset rather than a change in process. He warns against hiding behind definitions and processes, and encourages individuals to care about everything, as start-ups do.
subject_orig: ownership, productivity, software development, Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI), roles and responsibilities, start-ups
subject: ownership, productivity, software development, Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI), roles and responsibilities, start-ups

title: Keeping Your 1 to 1s Fresh
paper_abstract: The article discusses the importance of 1 to 1 meetings between managers and employees and how to keep them fresh and engaging. It provides tips on better topics for discussion and techniques to make the meetings more interesting.
subject_orig: 1 to 1 meetings, management, personal development, goals, technology
subject: 1 to 1 meetings, management, personal development, goals, technology

title: Engineering Career Tracks
paper_abstract: The article presents the different career tracks for an individual contributor track and management track. It also provides an explainer that discusses the different tracks. More details are available on the Become an Effective Software Engineering Manager book.
subject: career track, engineering, management
